Description.val: This project funds cyber support to PEOs/PMs to include cybersecurity support to risk management framework, cyber engineering and architecture development, industry cybersecurity engagement, and cyber program oversight and governance, which ensures the secure, affordable, and effective delivery of Army materiel solutions that address critical Army modernization objectives, as well as the delivery of agile and advanced cyber solutions to equip the Army?s offensive and defensive forces in the cyberspace domain. These funds support synchronization, analysis and integration of Cyber functions and products.

Text.val:
Operations:
- Led ASA(ALT) coordination, tracking, and tasking for named cyber operations, Army Cyber Command (ARCYBER) orders, and directives.  Led Army/ASA(ALT) taskers for the Cyber Focal, ensuring they are coordinated with the appropriate PEOs, PM, and organizations for a thorough, on-time response.  Coordinated priorities and tasks for ASA(ALT) from senior leadership forums.

Cybersecurity:
- Provided comprehensive cybersecurity expertise across ASA(ALT).  Oversaw the assessment and authorization of all ASA(ALT) owned and sponsored information systems, with direct support and oversight for PM PNT, USAASC, and DASA-P systems.  Oversaw the ASA(ALT) cybersecurity workforce and led the cybersecurity program for the Office of the Chief Systems Engineer (OCSE) / System of Systems Engineering and Integration (SoSE&I), and for the Army Rapid Capabilities Office (RCO).  Supported PEO Information Systems Security Manager efforts including Risk Management Framework (RMF), communications security (COMSEC) management, Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) compliance, and Command Cyber Readiness Inspections (CCRI).  Provided expertise to PMs for the approval, configuration and implementation of cross-domain solutions (CDS). Directly reported issues to ARCYBER and HQDA CIO/G-6.  Supported the development and review of DoD/Army regulations and policy. Fulfilled cybersecurity functions mandated by public law, federal directives, and DoD/Army policy.

- Led the cybersecurity program for Network Integration Evaluation (NIE) 18.2 across all phases of planning and execution.  Oversaw the ?authority to connect? process as the Authorizing Official for NIE and assessed risk for over 200 individual type systems.  Led cybersecurity pre-execution efforts with system owners including lab-based risk reduction, compliance pre-scans, blue team coordination, and vulnerable management/mitigation.  Continued risk management coordination throughout NIE/Joint Warfighter Assessment (JWA) Strategic Planning Reviews (SPRs), bullpen sessions, and architecture reviews.  Provided technical coordination for integrating cross-domain solutions (CDS). Continuously monitored the NIE RMF policy record, which reduces the time spent completing RMF by providing a set of 179 controls and 478 assessment procedures for participating systems.  The policy record received an additional one-year Authority to Operate (ATO), and it saves each PM/System Owner approximately 1000 work-hours per NIE/JWA.

- Provided rapid cybersecurity and CDS expertise to enable RCO deployment of critical electronic warfare system (VROD/VMAX) to USAREUR theater of operation.  Completed all requirements for system authorization in extremely-compressed timeframe. Achieved authorization of the first tactical small-form-factor CDS from the DoD Security Authorization Work Group (DSAWG) through multiple security assessments, documentation, developmental testing, and senior-leader engagements. 

- Led the pilot for ASA(ALT) in creating the RMF Tactical Policy Record, which streamlines the RMF process by reducing the workload for PMs by 500+ controls and sub-controls.

- Led the ASA(ALT) community in preparing for both planned and unannounced Command Cyber Readiness Inspections (CCRI).  Assisted local Network Enterprise Centers with acquiring critical support for patching and configuring PoR systems to increase cyber posture and achieve passing scores.  Supported 7th Signal Command as the PEO liaison.

- Established and co-led the Chief Information Officer (CIO) / Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) Council for ASA(ALT). This council provides the PEOs a forum to exchange ideas and issues within the organization as well as the basis to inform and shape larger Army governance bodies. 

Mission Assurance / Resilience:
- Facilitated technical exchange across ASA(ALT) community by maintaining Cyber Focal SharePoint sites to support partner efforts: Host-Based Security System (HBSS) waivers, unsupported software, Windows 10 Migration, vulnerability management, Cyber Acquisition Task Force, Innovation Challenge, and Cyber I-WSR.  Also facilitated internal coordination across Cyber Programs, CIO Governance, Mission Assurance & Resilience, Cybersecurity, Defense Industrial Base. 

- Provided technical expertise to the mandated Windows 10 Migration across the Army; focused on weapon systems and addressed office IT.  Assisted prioritization of systems that can migrate versus those requiring a waiver.  Identified systems that may never migrate due to inherent constraints (e.g., embedded Windows system, stand-alone system, etc.).  Tracked unsupported Microsoft servers and operating systems.  Provided findings and analysis to the monthly DoD Cybersecurity Scorecard. 

- Co-led the FY16 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) Section 1647 Cyber Vulnerabilities Assessments based on the Chairman's Prioritization and the Quadrennial Design Review.  Determined scope and then coordinated across PEOs, ARCYBER, ATEC, HQDA G-3/5/7, and others to meet NDAA requirements.  Analyzed and reviewed with stakeholders both completed and planned cyber assessments, as well as what additional assessments could further evaluate system vulnerabilities from a risk-to-mission perspective.  Collaborated to provide recommendations and critical path for mitigations. 

- Provided critical input for the emerging Cyber Operational Risk Assessment ? Platform (CORA-P), which is the Army?s enduring effort to continue 1647 activities.  Assessments will address six-to-eight systems per year, and will identify priority cyber mitigations for PM implementation.  Interfaced with the Threat System Management Office (TSMO) both to support Cyber Red Team activities and to address Joint Staff requests for input to DoD Red Team standards, policies, training, etc. 

- Engaged HQDA G-2 to understand and improve intelligence support to the acquisition lifecycle.  Attended intelligence summit to discuss gaps in support and necessary information for materiel development.  The largest gap is the understanding and capacity to integrate foreign intelligence officers (FIO) at PMs.  

Engineering: 
- Provided multidisciplinary engineering expertise to support Rapid Capabilities Office (RCO).  Improved scope and framing relevance for power fingerprinting (PFP) analysis; provided technical assessment and alternative solutions for Advanced Cyber Hardening with PM Distributed Common Ground System-Army (DCGS-A); progressively elaborated technical options for Project Kyber roadmap; and developed technical campaign plan for Rodeo Framework.  These all improved RCO understanding of the technical capabilities and limitations for each effort, and enabled the strategic prioritization of resources.  

- Coordinated establishment of the Army-wide Cyberspace Supply Chain Risk Management (CySCRM) Working Group (WG) via HQDA EXORD.  This strategic WG has assembled representatives from over twenty Army organizations in order to identify holistic solutions that address threat actions in cyberspace as well defend information systems.  The WG is identifying and will institutionalize cross-organizational improvements in order for ASA(ALT) to realize improved integration, efficiency, and effectiveness of Army-wide SCRM efforts.  In parallel, coordinated and improved OSD and joint-service execution of NDAA-11 Section-806 authorities to manage critical threats to national security systems.  Established the process by which Army conducts operational impact assessments to exclude validated high-threat actors, coordinated its implementation, and synchronized across the services. 

- Provided technical leadership for the Army-wide Electronic Patching Initiative to improve asset identification and vulnerability management for PoR systems.  Implemented an integrated engineering and program management approach to achieve multiple lines of effort.  Prepared work breakdown structure, schedule, and roles/responsibilities.  Improved the community awareness of tasks, timeliness of execution, strategic communications, and progression of a minimum viable product (MVP) approach to complete a Pilot.  OCSE identified this effort as a crosscutting innovation to the ASA(ALT) Principle Deputy.

- ASA(ALT) coordination lead for Unified Platform (UP) / Joint Cyber Command & Control (JCC2), which are joint programs delivering crosscutting OCO, DCO, and SU capabilities.  Established a recurring forum to coordinate efforts between Army cyber programs, HQDA staff, and TRADOC.  Provided strategic subject matter expertise to help bridge the development of joint solutions with diverse Army projects across four PEOs.  Identified new opportunities for cost sharing between DoD Executive Agent and ASA(ALT) PMs.

- Co-led Army-wide coordination for the FY19 Implementation Plan for Line of Effort-3 ?Capability Development? of the Army Cyberspace Strategy (ACyS).  This plan is a SECARMY directed requirement to assure strategic implementation of the ACyS.  This plan resulted in a comprehensive set of by-name action items that promote responsive and agile requirements/capability development; measures resourcing; enhances acquisition and sustainment; supports modernization of cybersecurity technology; and enables Army unity of effort across DCO, Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO), and Department of Defense Information Network (DoDIN) operations.  This plan innovated new action items across the acquisition lifecycle.  Throughout coordination, stakeholders gained an understanding of mid-tier acquisition, evolving requirements processes, emerging Science & Technology (S&T) projects, and institutional developments.

- Initiated a strategic effort to improve the system security engineering (SSE) function within ASA(ALT).  SSE is a critical sub-discipline of SE that ensures all stages within system lifecycles identify and address stakeholder protection needs and security concerns.  Synchronized SSE with information system security managers across ASA(ALT), led discussion with OSD and PEO Chief Engineers at the Army SE Forum (ASEF), prepared SSE-relevant checklists to review program protection plans, and synchronized efforts with SSE leaders from other services. 

- Provided to the OSD Deputy Director for Cyber a framework for crosscutting technology assessments.  Such capabilities (e.g. containerization, data obfuscation, Initial Operational Test (IoT) security) can have wide use, but no single PM may have the requirement or expertise.  This effort resulted in a FY18 cost savings of approximately $1M, schedule savings of six-months, and it allowed OSD to meet critical suspense to congressional inquiry.

In collaboration with the Army Intelligence and Security Command, secure funding to update information technology to meet future damage assessment demands.
Work with the OSD Damage Assessment Management Office to modernize damage assessment tool suites to manage increased incident reporting and to identify trends in unauthorized technology transfers.
Continue to integrate CIDA operations with Joint Acquisition Protection & Exploitation Cell (JAPEC) to facilitate proactive protection of Army controlled technical information (CTI) residing and transiting on contractor-owned systems.
Update AR 70-77 to codify CTI identification and safeguarding processes and to improve intelligence support to CIDA process.
Conduct cost benefit analysis additional Army resource requirements to meet JAPEC needs.  Assist PEOs, PMs, and ASA(ALT) with forecasting costs and resources required with protection of CTI within the DIB, damage assessment recovery operations, and maintaining technology superiority.

Strategic:
Lead a coordinated, comprehensive acquisition approach to enhance cyber resiliency and survivability across ASA(ALT) communities and the materiel enterprise.  Optimize cybersecurity as a critical enabler of capability delivery.  Facilitate and ensure execution of cyber-related tasks and efforts by appropriate ASA(ALT) organizations.  Represent and advocate for ASA(ALT) cyberspace equities in external governance bodies, senior leader forums, and partner engagements.  Shape cyberspace policy, directives and orders that may impact acquisition.  Deliver systemic and crosscutting value to PMs executing cyber-related missions. 

Cybersecurity:
Lead the cybersecurity program for ASA(ALT).  Fulfill cybersecurity functions mandated by public law, federal directives, and DoD/Army policy, and ensure PEOs and organizations meet all requirements.  Perform delegated Authorizing Official functions for ASA(ALT), ensuring HQ Business systems maintain an acceptable level of risk and continue authorization throughout the system lifecycle.  Provide oversight and management standards for the ASA(ALT) cybersecurity workforce.  Support PEOs in implementing the Risk Management Framework, communications security (COMSEC) management, Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) compliance, and Command Cyber Readiness Inspections (CCRI).  Provide technical support to facilitate compliance with ARCYBER orders and directives addressing software updates, patching, reporting, and named cyber operations. 

Support the secure operation of ASA(ALT) activities.  Lead coordination across PEOs in preparing for both planned and unannounced Command Cyber Readiness Inspections (CCRI).  Assist local Network Enterprise Centers as needed to support ASA(ALT) equities.  Engage 7th Signal Command as the PEO liaison.  Report to HQDA CIO/G-6 and ARCYBER for cybersecurity related requirements and issues.  Monitor and coordinate response to the various cybersecurity inspection programs and audit findings related to Department of Defense Inspector General (DoDIG), APPA, and  Army Audit Agency (AAA) audits.

Co-lead RMF process improvement initiatives for the Army, lead for ASA(ALT).  In connection with (ICW) HQDA CIO/G-6 and NETCOM, ensure resources are available to conduct further pilot efforts.  Develop policies, procedures, and lessons learned to ensure RMF optimization for the Army.

Co-lead the ASA(ALT) Chief Information Officer (CIO)/Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) Council. Ensure PEO involvement and coordination to meet the objectives and requirements identified in the council charter. 

Support critical modernization of unsupported software for secure operations.  Monitor and facilitate PEO/PM migration plans and execution away from unsupported client/server operating systems and applications (e.g. Windows 10, Server 2003).  Assist and respond with data call requests, synchronization efforts, and IPRs with DoD CIO, HQDA CIO/G-6, ARCYBER, and the Vice Chief of Staff of the Army (VCSA).  Provide required data to support DoD Cybersecurity Scorecard.

Coordinate DoD and Army requirements for public key infrastructure (PKI) and Multi-Factor Authentication across PEOs and PMs.  Coordinate and review all program briefings, and input to the PKE Exemption SharePoint site. 

Coordinate priorities and tasks for ASA(ALT) from senior leadership forums such as the CIO Executive Board (CIO-EB).

Provide holistic expertise and support for Cross-Domain Solutions (CDS). Establish and facilitate Army Tactical CDS WG to provide collaboration among tactical program stakeholders. Identify requirements and interoperability issues affecting multiple systems in the tactical space.  Evaluate emerging CDS technologies for the tactical environment and provide feedback to industry to shape investments.  

Mission Assurance/Resilience & Engineering:
Facilitate technical exchange across ASA(ALT) community by maintaining Cyber Focal SharePoint site to collect and main PoR data as needed.  Offload legacy data to authoritative sources/repositories as feasible.  Facilitate internal coordination across Cyber Focal. 

Support Cyber Operational Resiliency Assessment-Platform (CORA-P) program.  Facilitate identification, prioritization, and approval of vulnerability mitigations and advanced cyber hardening efforts for critical systems. Leverage lessons learned and analyses opportunities to further cyber resiliency goals. 

Enhance cyber assessments within acquisition process. Coordinate with testing community, PMs/PEOs, OSD/Joint Staff, to implement improvements to cyber assessment process across all ASA(ALT) lifecycles.  This process will build on the community-established needs to better integrate testing (Red/Blue/Cyber Ranges), supply chain risk management (beyond Trusted Systems & Networks process), cyber teams (certification/standards), threat capabilities/intent, and risk-to-mission perspective.  Institutionalize lessons learned and guidance via Army Acquisition Executive (AAE) directive for PM training and implementation. 

Enhance cyberspace acquisition governance.  Operationalize the Cyber Acquisition Task Force (CATF) to synchronize and prioritize cyberspace capabilities in coordination with other critical governance forums.  Army requires whole-of-service governance approach to accelerate and provide flexible delivery of cyberspace capabilities.  Establish clear battle-rhythm with TCM Cyber, ARCYBER, and DAMO-CY G-3/5/7 working and assessment group.  Integrate with CCIDS Configuration Control Board (CCB) and Cyberspace Requirements Evaluation Board (CREB).  Ensure communications across the community.  

Provide ASA(ALT) technical representation and expertise at Unified Platform (UP) and Joint Cyberspace Command & Control (JCC2) decision forums.  Ensure technical compatibility of joint efforts with current/planned Army systems across PEOs and advocate for Army programmatic equities in cyberspace.  Specifically, Army will maximize coordination of Army capability and materiel development, to ensure both align to and support UP/JCC2 objectives.  Improve communication and information sharing across all stakeholders to support PEO interests.  

Improve ASA(ALT) System Security Engineering (SSE).  Set conditions for the formal appointment of the SSE workforce within each PEO.  Establish duties with prescribed training, experience, and certification requirements IAW DoD 8570.  Facilitate collaboration across ASA(ALT), and with the cybersecurity community.  

Improve cyberspace supply chain risk management (CySCRM).  Support OCSE efforts with Army CySCRM WG to maintain readiness of Army forces, capabilities, and systems by identifying, scoping, and mitigating risks to the supply chain.  The WG will provide a forum for stakeholders to review intelligence reports and assessments related to SCRM; review current SCRM policies, roles, and responsibilities; identify potential gaps; recommend mitigations; in accordance with AR 70-77, maximize the integration of SCRM across system lifecycles; and interface with joint and interagency SCRM activities to ensure whole-of-government execution.  

As needed, conduct engineering assessments of crosscutting cyber focused architectures, solutions, and capabilities proposed by PORs, CFTs, and RCO.

*Project FG7 Emerging Technology Initiatives was created in support of the Army Rapid Capabilities Office (RCO). This project was realigned to PE 0605054A Emerging Technologies Initiatives in FY 2019 for greater transparency of the Army RCO efforts.

ProjectMissionDescription.val:
This Project funds the prototyping and demonstration of selected technology enabled capabilities to support advanced Soldier, ground, aviation, and Command, Control, Communications, Computers Intelligence & Reconnaissance (C4ISR) systems and equipment.

The Primary goal is to take technologies to Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 7 and 8 through a collaborative and accelerated acquisition process. Technologies will be demonstrated in relevant environments, performing tactical/operational scenarios. Efforts will focus on high-priority, threat-based projects with the intent to deliver an operationally effective capability within one to five years. Efforts will include accelerated material development and competitive prototyping based on anticipated and emerging threats and opportunities. This Project provides the Army an improved mechanism to effectively confront emerging threats and advance America's military dominance. Efforts include development, acquisition, assessment, maturation, and transition of prototype technologies to acquisition programs in Cyber; Electronic Warfare (EW); Positioning, Navigation and Timing (PNT); Survivability and other high priority emerging threats and opportunities. Funds may also allow for acceleration of critical Program of Record capabilities to counter urgent and emerging threats. The Army Rapid Capabilities Office (RCO) assesses the provided capabilities to improve future solutions, to inform future Army capability requirements, and to potentially transition the capability to an Army acquisition program.

The Army RCO expedites the provisioning and fielding of critical combat materiel capabilities to the Warfighter to meet Combatant Commanders' needs. The Army RCO was established per Headquarters, Department of the Army, memo, SUBJECT: Establishment of the Army Rapid Capabilities Office, signed by the Secretary of the Army: Eric K. Fanning, dated 11 August 2016.

The RCO assesses Commercial-Off-The Shelf (COTS), Government Off-The- Shelf (GOTS), and Non-Developmental Item (NDI) (non-standard equipment) solutions for modification and/or integration to address changes in contested environments with enduring materiel solutions for forces deployed globally. Procure prototypes and evaluate solutions to be fielded and transition to an acquisition program for production and sustainment.   

The RCO capabilities focus areas are:
Cyber
Electronic Warfare (EW)
Position, Navigation and Timing (PNT)
Survivability
Operational Needs Statements (ONS)
Any other operational needs that become a priority as designated by the Army Board of Directors (BOD)

Title.val: Maturation, Prototyping, Assessment, and Integration of Emerging and Essential Technologies

Description.val: This effort selects technologies that show high promise for advancing and accelerating capabilities required under acquisition programs and develops and evaluates associated prototypes for accelerated identification, assessment, and transition to an acquisition program for production and fielding. It also demonstrates integrated technologies within a high fidelity and realistic operating environment and transitions them to a formal program of record on an accelerated basis. This effort also includes analysis, integration and evaluation of emerging capabilities on air and ground platforms to reduce risk and support technology insertions.

Text.val:
These funds were used to identify, develop, procure, modify, and evaluate prototypes providing capability prioritized by the Board of Directors (BOD) in the areas of Cyber, EW, PNT, Survivability, and Other critical capability gaps. Funding supported infrastructure, procurement of prototypes, engineering and material for integration, field support representation, early acquisition documentation, system modification, and development and operational testing needed to transition a procurement ready solution to an acquisition program for execution. 

Electronic Warfare Phase 1 Requirements (In support of USAREUR ONS ? 16-21509) -  continued integration and assessment that began in FY 2017 for Ground EW capability with enhanced and networked capability for Prophet, Versatile Radio Observation & Direction Finding (VROD) / Modular Adaptive Transmitter (VMAX) and Sabre Junction. 

Electronic Warfare Phase 2 Requirements (In support of USAREUR ONS ? 16-21509) - continued integration and assessment that began in FY 2017 of air EW capability. Funding acquired long lead prototypes, conducted non-recurring integration engineering and risk reduction exercises, and enabled further development of ground EW prototype capabilities.

Positioning, Navigation and Timing Phase 1 Requirements (In support of USAREUR ONS ? 16-21509) - continued integration and assessment of the DAGR Distributed Device Enhancement (D3E) w/Anti-Jam (AJ) Antenna and Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) Sensors. Non-recurring engineering and integration of the D3E/AJ onto the Bradley, Abrams, Stryker and Paladin platforms was conducted in FY 2018 to obtain a Capabilities and Limitations (C&L) report to enable Urgent Materiel Release (UMR).

Funding was used in support of the Long Range Cannon project to fund Projectile Tracking System development. Funded 305 XM1113 projectiles for the qualification of the 55 caliber tube.  Funded one Location and Azimuth Determining System. Additionally funded the M777 Extended Range adapter kits and hardware integration support. 

Artificial Intelligence ? identified and enabled signal classification leveraging machine learning for signals of interest and user interface augmentation leveraging expert learning artificial intelligence to support electronic warfare operational requirements. Funding acquired algorithm prototypes, and conducted non-recurring integration engineering and risk reduction exercises. These activities will enable further development of artificial intelligence prototype capabilities.

Cyber (Cyber Counter UAS (Darkbridge)). These funds were used to develop and field ten prototype systems and accompanying mounting packages for support to 3-1CD?s NTC rotation and follow on OCONUS deployment. The development served as risk reduction for follow on prototype phases with an expanded user base. RCO will build on this initial investment to develop a modular Darkbridge Software package for integration with other Army EW and C-UAS platforms.

AcquisitionStrategy.val: The Army RCO capitalizes on current and emerging technologies to provide rapid solutions to address emerging threats and high impact capability opportunities of U.S. Army Forces deployed globally. This is accomplished in one of two ways: 1) adapting COTS/GOTS/NDI equipment to meet operational needs and 2) developing emerging deployable capability through research and development organizations, academia, and industry. The RCO uses streamlined acquisition methods, processes and techniques to rapidly acquire capability; these methods vary by project. The Rapid Capabilities Office will have a dedicated contracting staff, with the flexibility to use both traditional and non-traditional contracting approaches. To reach non-traditional vendors, RCO will use non-standard contracting methods, such as Other Transaction Authority instruments. Where practicable, prototypes will be acquired using competitive procedures. Projects will be transitioned to an approved acquisition program for production and sustainment. Operational assessments will be conducted to provide feedback in support of Army requirements generation, prototype maturation, and future capability development.
